The co-writer here is Joss Whedon, perhaps the most famous name attached to the project. Writer and director is Drew Goddard, an Oscar nominee for his "The Martian" script now. Oh wait, "Thor" Chris Hemsworth is in these 95 minutes too, so he is probably the biggest name. This is what happens when 5 young adults go on a trip to the location mentioned in the title. Not much later, the first zombies show up. But what sets this movie apart from every generic zombie horror film is that a major plot in here is a bit of a horror equivalent of "The Truman Show". Certainly not a coincidence that the only guy who sees the entire thing critical is also called Truman. Or newer generations not familiar with the Jim Carrey film can also compare it a bit to The Hunger Games. Anyway, this surveillance plot stars Jenkins and Acker and Whitford and I like all three of them which made this part of the story location-wise almost as interesting as the core story. That part is also where you will find most of the comedy and this comedic stuff is where the film works best.

Or I could say perhaps too "the only part where it works" as the more serious dramatic parts just never felt convincing, especially the nerdy stoner guy surviving really everything and turning into some bad-ass superhero almost. Was this done for the nerds, for them to like this movie to have the nerd survive next to the hot chick until the very end? Perhaps. If so, it was a success. As for him, he also only delivered in terms of comedy. As for the horror moments, the film is pretty generic for the most part and the revelation of these monster chambers is also more quantity than quality. Plus the way they make fun of themselves towards the end with the horny promiscuous chick dying first, moments after exposing her breasts of course, cannot save it overall. Same for the virgin references about Connolly's character. It is also a fairly manipulative movie that wants us to put friendship over the existence of humanity. But it never poses a question of moral. It makes very clear what it wants the audience to think on several occasions and there it only works for the easily influenced and entertained. Successfully as I saw from other reactions in the audience. It is what it is, eventually an apocalyptic horror comedy that for me only worked from the comedy perspective. Some fairly witty ideas in here, but story-wise the execution could have been a lot better. I recommend it nonetheless I think, even if the recognition by IMDb voters, awards bodies and critics is definitely on the exaggerated side. See it if you like the genre(s).

title: Interesting take on the teenage horror genre
review:
I have some mixed feelings about this movie, but I know why that is. Although meant to be that way, the representations of the characters - whore, scholar, jock, stoner and virgin - were so one dimensional that I had trouble connecting with any of them. None of the main characters had any depth and I had a little bit of trouble with that. After it is all said and done though, it makes sense that they were portrayed that way.

There were also a few parts in the movie that didn't make much sense to me. Although I'm not going to write any specific spoilers, my understanding is that the cabin belonged to a family member of one of the characters. And how did the powers that be know that those particular college students were going to be there? And how did they get into their stuff?

The movie is worth a watch, if for nothing else because of the unique take on the genre. I really did enjoy that - I thought I was in for the same ol' same ol' - not so much!! The CGI and special effects are also worth a watch, and you'll see some quite interesting props as well! And you might be left with the question, as I was, of "Who are the real monsters here?"

title: At Times Thriling, Sometimes Funny, Never Consistent,
review:
The Cabin in the Woods is a good movie with a reasonably well developed plot and a talented cast. It's a very interesting concept that is executed very well, it also keeps us intrigued throughout, wondering what exactly is going on, and not truly finding what out the reason for these events are until the very end. The massive selection of movie monster is very impressive, and the sequence at the end was immensely thrilling.

While I definitely get why some people would love the genre mix in this movie, I was not particularly fond of it. The film is half raunchy comedy, half straight up horror, but because of that it was never really consistent. There were moments where you could be in fear, and then suddenly hit with a ridiculous joke that completely took me out of it. They are both such different brands of film that they did not work out very much together for me.

The character development is poor. I think the five young adults that we follow at the beginning should have been fleshed out more, as it is them we are following on this bizarre journey. We should have cared for all of them and want each one to come out of this alive, but we are never truly given a reason to.

It is certainly entertaining, albeit never engrossing. A great story and terrific suspense, Cabin in the Woods has its flaws, but it's worth the watch if you are looking for a good horror, just do not go out of your way to see it.

Five teens get far more than they bargained for when they spend a weekend at an isolated cabin.

Best Performance: Richard Jenkins / Worst Performance: Anna Hutchison

title: Take a trip into the woods
review:
Cabin in the woods is a master piece taking the horror tropes and turning them on there heads.

Taking all the monsters from past and present genres they are dumped into a battleground feel within the woods.

Its not easy to pull this off, like Freddy and Jason proved, but each got scare time and never once made it feel over the top.

Joss Whedon can take the stereotype of a jock, a princess, virgin, lower and pot head and give them layers you or I have. They really seem like teenagers you would find on a college campus.

The plot never once felt lacking or needed improvement and there isn't a chance for a sequel to squander the magic of the first.

One thing I can appreciate about horror is if the comedy works with the scares and it pulls it off in strides. The dark humor is sprinkled in the dialogue and situations in unique places you wouldn't expect to find it.

The ending was truly brilliant and can't be topped. 10 for 10

title: Better than expected but ultimately so-so
review:
Five teens go to an isolated cabin in the woods for a weekend. In the basement of the cabin they find an assortment of relics, books and ancient artefacts. In reading from a book they then inadvertently summon a family of zombie killers. However, they've only just scratched the surface of what the cabin is hiding.

Pleasantly surprised, but ultimately disappointing. Was expecting your average (i.e. crap) horror movie but for the first 60% or so of the movie it was very interesting. Intriguing, engaging and, most surprising, funny.

From a point, however, it degenerates into your usual humans-vs- ghouls/zombies schlock, and from then on it is incredibly formulaic and tiresome.

title: bloodily bad taste in horror
review: Saturday, hot autumn afternoon, there I was looking for an entertainment, so, why not Cabin in the Woods, it was right there totally available What i am going to say next it is not for those who are into blodily movies. ...40 minutes into the movie, and they lost it, the rest I fast forwarded and the question remained: Why do they make movies such as this one? What a terrible taste and waste of resources, really I wish I could ask Sigourney Weaver and Richard Jenkins if they ever watched the movie after they had shot all their scenes, I doubt very much so I wish I knew what it takes for a well-known, and actually good actor chose the film they will be in it. In a movie such as this one, maybe they did it for money, there isn't any other explanation You can say that Cabin in the Woods is the meeting point between ridiculous and nasty; a bloodily bad taste in horror movies.

title: Quite entertaining
review:
This film tells the story of five friends going to a remote cabin for a holiday. Little do they know that there is something very sinister going on in the cabin, and soon they find themselves fighting for their dear lives.

"The Cabin in the Woods" looks a bit like a low budget film because of the harsh lighting and the way visuals are presented. However, it has Chris Hemsworth and Richard Jenkins in it, so it can't be a low budget film. Sigourney Weaver appears right in the end too, which is quite a pleasant surprise for me! As for the story, it is interesting and entertaining. The gory horror scenes are so over the top that they are comedic at times. It is a bit wrong to chuckle at these scenes but I cannot help it. Overall, the film is certainly different from other horror films, and is quite entertaining.

title: Surprise, surprise
review:
Going in, all I knew was that this one had Thor headlining, and that one/more of the brains behind 'Lost' had dreamt this up. Also, on the negative side, the focus was more on the production, distribution and release delays, which never augur well for any flick, esp. when Thor had something similar going on with the 'Red dawn' remake (and we all know how 'classic' that turned out).

Anyway, any fears I had were unfounded. This one turned out to be, simply, one of the most intelligent, and gleefully irreverent take on various genres, including schlock-horror. From one mind-bending twist to the next mind-numbing one, this one doesn't allow anyone to relax, and keeps pushing our buttons all through, defying/sending up all the genre conventions, without descending to parody.

The casting and the acting are apt, with Weaver and Jenkins making welcome appearances, and nothing is what meets the eye.

Surely the makings of a cult classic - Try ignoring reviews written by morons who give everything away, and be prepped to be pleasantly surprised by this masterwork, the likes of which will be rare to watch once again on the big screen. And yeah, take your significant other, and watch it on the big screen.

title: One word to describe this movie: CRAP
review: Because this flick got 7.1 ratings, I couldn't stop writing my first ever review on IMDb. The movie has no storyline, no terrifying moment. I begged for it to end, hoping for something interesting to come by. I wonder who voted 10 for this movie, probably this was their first horror movie. There are thousands of good movies that do justice to their genre. This movie is a proof that movies cannot be watched based on IMDb ratings. A classic like "Drag me to hell" has lower ratings than this crap. If you haven't watched it yet, Good for you, stay away and save your time. After climax, I was like what have I just watched? Come on guys! Be fair with the ratings, as I was fooled into watching this crap.

title: Creative Failure
review:
I began watching this movie with an open-mind, but 10 minutes into the movie I just wanted to return it to my local movie store and demand a refund. My first thought, "It's a cheap adult version of Scooby-Doo," my second thought, "I would rather be watching the Live-Action Scooby-Doo." Let's be honest, that version wasn't too great either!

Not that it needs to be said, but I was highly disappointed with this film, I thought it had potential to break free from standard horror films. Unfortunately, it was just like any typical college thriller; the biggest disappointment came from the zombies. Out of all those mystical, blood- thirsty beings seen later on...the initial monsters were zombies. Seriously, why not that pterodactyl thing?

All in all, this movie is a disappointing and overrated creative failure.

title: This could be better...
review:
Hi there!

I watch the movie last night, and I felt uncomfortable with some comments. This movie is overrated. I agree that your subject is well chosen, but the development of his production team leaves much to be desired.

Before I begin, let me make clear that I love certain productions of joss whedon also, it's very original, and in this movie as well. My problematic is the ultimate succession of facts before the apocalyptic end. Earlier, the allusion of typical American teenager, led most to think: "cliché". And in fact is a cliché, not only this part, but like many others throughout the movie, and successive allusions to other films, creating what I consider a great parody. Until then OK. That old man appear to then, the messenger, talking a lot of weird stuff, and then an eagle colliding in a field of force, which does not match the level of technology of this alternate world, but OK too. From then on, had all the horror / comedy movie construction, with a complex symbolism and even interesting, although nothing funny, which generated a relaxed atmosphere and creating a tension between the constant alternation of seriousness and comedy.

Skipping various parts, I was well entertained with the movie and enjoying a lot, got the party marty resurfaces from the dead, and saves dana. Genial, I expected something to happen, as they put it clear that she would survive or not. But wait, how they managed to lose marty? Continuing, they enter the tomb, which is kind of a place for maintenance, has the lift, I think they get a good escape, arriving at the building, causing all the destruction.

Now comes the second change, which is the main part of the displeasure of several reviews scattered around the internet. The fact is, okay they are invisible to the monsters distributed by the environment, that is the only premise that ensures a decent ending to the film. They escape, arriving in the rituals room, and it appears that woman, that must be some of the upstairs-guys, unarmed to talk? Please!! After the werewolf appears, then the little girl buckner, not being fulfilled the established ritual, arousing the anger of the elder gods, and it all ends in a spectacle of dreadful graphics effects (is so damn easy to make, they could have improved it). But, from another premise, that the gods have always existed, how they were regulated before? How were neutralized? I don't see this as a burden for me, but as a problem for the author.

So, concluding this huge text, the film is well developed to the point where they begin to arise false assertions to ensure the end, without worrying about the "vision" of the viewer, breaking the mix of events. It had everything to be great, but eventually became a movie with obvious conclusions, without parts that cause fear, or bring smiles, with one thing or another original in its content. There are many things I would like to mention in this text, but as is already too big, it ends here. 5/10

title: Cute but too aware of its own cuteness
review:
I watched too much West Wing. Bradley's Josh made me want to like this from the get go.

The formula's there, it's known, it's easy to understand, and off we went with five young people who's going to enjoy a vacation at a cabin in the middle of nowhere. OK.

Gas station. OK. Done. Weird cabin. OK. Swim. Truth or Dare. Cellar. Latin incantation. OK. Now people started to die. Then it turned onto itself and more people died.

(Bradley's self-prophesized death was a little too silly for me. It's the type that elicited a polite chuckle from the audience just cuz that particular audience is making an effort to like the movie.) To be honest, it really relied very much on the audience being a big horror genre fan for the extra kicks. But, I enjoyed it, it was a cute ride. I wished it was a bit more, but whatever, selfish teenagers ruined humanity. OK. Doesn't matter. I still think it was pretty cute.

But then, something bothered me. They said all other rituals had failed in the world. But horror genre differs from culture to culture. And, the five archetype of sacrifices wouldn't have worked in the movie's own Japanese counterpart. There were no athlete, nor whore, and presumably everyone was virginal in the 9-years-old set up telecasted from Kyoto.

I wished logic would just shut up sometimes when I'm watching horror. But then again, it's Joss Whedon, and his quirky, cute, grating, self-satisfied writing had ran its course by the end of the movie.

5/10

title: mixed feelings about this one.
review:
This movie was really strange. I have never really heard anything about it then after seeing mixed reviews on here I decided to give it a viewing and see what I thought of it. I cant even decide how I feel about it really. At first the movie started off good and I was intrigued by the original idea. Though as he movie progressed it kept getting more and more ridiculous and convoluted.

I cant really explain what this movie is about without giving away spoilers. This movie is very confusing but not terrible. The first half was an enjoyable mix of horror/comedy but the second half was just garbage. I suggest you stay away from this one despite all the good reviews on this site.

I am a true horror fan and I did not like it though it was not the worst movie I've seen.

title: A horror fan's wet dream!
review:
'THE CABIN IN THE WOODS': Five Stars (Out of Five)

The best reviewed movie of the year, so far, is this B slasher film from 'Nerd God' Joss Whedon! Whedon co-wrote and produced the film and his buddy, a usual partner in crime of his, Drew Goddard directed the film. The cast features new Whedon 'Go-To Man' Chris Hemsworth (who also plays 'Thor' in Whedon's upcoming 'AVENGERS' film). The film is a meta slasher flick spoof and the best of it's type since 'SCREAM' or possibly even 'EVIL DEAD II'!

The story revolves around five friends going on vacation at a remote cabin in the middle of the woods owned by Curt's (Hemsworth) cousin. Despite being warned of danger by a creepy gas station attendant (Tim De Zarn) they continue to the cabin and also investigate it's mysterious basement, which is full of strange artifacts. Meanwhile they're being watched by technicians at a government facility and we learn they're guinea pigs in some kind of experiment. The film constantly winks it's eye at the viewer as it runs through every horror cliché imaginable.

The movie is brilliantly tongue in cheek and the perfect homage to B horror films. The script is clever and the directing is perfectly fitting. The cast is all perfect in their roles (especially memorable turns from Fran Kranz, Richard Jenkins and Bradley Whitford). It's hilarious as well as perfectly gruesome (a horror fan's wet dream) and the climax is more than any monster movie fan could ask for. Classic Joss Whedon!

Watch our movie review show 'MOVIE TALK' at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZGSyQ_obeNo

title: Well... Lets just say it does it's job!
review: The Cabin in the Woods is amazing. It's action packed, horrifying, scary and yet funny at the same time. It picks up where 5 teenagers inhabit in a cabin way beyond the woods, however after an eventful day realise they're not alone in the woods... It is very creepy and has a lot of jumpy moments including... Zombies busting through cellar doors, A giant raptor smashing through a door with a blood trail to where several dead, mutilated bodies remain and freaky masked people! The main theme is disturbing, the fact that several people in 1 company are perversely watching 5 teens go through absolute hell! It has all you want in a horror film, gore, thrill, violence, sex, scares and suspense. It's just amazing! I would definitely recommend going to see this whenever you can because it is brilliant, sensational and just.... Creepily comical!

title: Amazing!
review: This is a truly extraordinary and intelligent film. The script is so witty and ingenious and the directing is flawless. The Cabin in the Woods subverts your expectations at every corner and makes you remember why you go to the movies. It is everything you could hope for in a horror film and more. Joss Whedon does an excellent job writing a funny, witty, scary script and Goddard does an amazing job in his directing debut. I recommend this film to anyone who appreciates good, genuine horror film, which are in short supply these days. The Cabin in the Woods is undoubtedly one of the best horror films of the last 20 years! Go See it!

title: Outstanding meta-movie
review:
I better preface this by say that I love both Drew Godard and Joss Whedon. Maybe that means I'm biased, but I thought this flick was completely awesome. It's not at all what I expected it to be; I say that having watched the initial trailer and thinking I already had a pretty good idea of what was up. I honestly expected it to be more scare oriented, but I wasn't at all disappointed with what it actually is. It's really really funny. I keep wanting to say spoilery things, even comparisons to other things could be spoilery. I love it when genre movies are made by people with a clear love of the films that came before and have an interesting take on a different look at it. This is a horror-lovers movie, it's a movie-lovers movie, it's a hell of a good time for people who just want to sit back and have a great ride, plus some gore.

All thumbs up.

title: "Cabin in the Woods" Rejuvenates a Tired Genre
review: "The Cabin in the Woods" is a slasher film for folks who don't like slasher films. That's because this film doesn't like the slasher genre either. It satirizes the hell out of it and then adds a heavy dose of repentance and Biblical-like retribution. There's some nice performances especially Kristen Connolly as Dana the intelligent and resourceful girl in the group of twenty-something explorers who venture into the wilderness and end up getting more adventure than they bargained for. Fran Kranz is very good as Marty the joker who has devised an ingenious delivery system for getting stoned. Chris Hemsworth and Anna Hutchison are the jock and his girlfriend. Completing the group is Jesse Williams as Holden the serious-minded college student who declines an opportunity to see Dana au natural. There's also a family straight out of "Night of the Living Dead" and a mysterious group of techie types who observe and manipulate Dana and friends according to some preconceived plan. If Wes Craven began the process of poking fun at slasher films, Goddard and Whedon have added self-criticism and social commentary while keeping you entertained throughout.

title: The God of all horrors !
review:
Wow this movie was amazing and I don't mean that just because I love horror movies, its because this movie is the smartest movie I've seem in years. I don't no how Joss and Drew wrote this but they managed to make a horror classic. First let's start with the characters they are typical horror roles,the Jock (Curt), the Whore (Jules), the Scholar (Holden), the Druggie (Marty) and the sweet Virgin (Dana). Each one of them was fantastic at acting and keeping straight faces my personal favorite was Marty mainly because he is hilarious and high half the time. The creatures and CGI were fantastic the creators did a nice job at making them. The story is about 5 friends taking a break at a cabin, when they unknowingly awake the Zombie Redneck Tortured Family from there sleep in the ground (or is it). while this is happening you see two colleges on the way to the secret operation what is apparently in competition with Japan later you find out what there real intentions are, which all leads up to the thrilling 20 minute finale which is an absolute bloodbath. oh and the twist is totally unexpected. (Well it was for me).

So I would strongly recommend this to horror fans and also people who aren't .

10/10

title: Great twist on a overdone genre
review:
In his feature film directorial debut, Drew Goddard (a writer for "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," "Angel" and "Lost" TV series, the film "Cloverfield") has taken a tired film formula, the teen slasher flick, and turned it on its head. It's "The Truman Show" meets "Friday the 13th" meets "The Evil Dead," which just a little "Ghostbusters" added to the concoction.

The result is a welcome, refreshing change of pace which is at once exhilarating, frightening, thought-provoking and drop-dead hilarious. And it's certainly a huge step up from 2007's "Cloverfield," which was shot in Confuse-O-Vision and populated by pretty but incompetent actors.

Here, there are a few recognizable faces (Richard Jenkins, "Step Brothers," "The Rum Diary" and Bradley Whitford, "Billy Madison, "The West Wing" TV series) among the young — and mostly unknown — thespians, which goes a long way in establishing a sense of credibility the above-mentioned film could never muster.

In "Cabin," a group of stereotypical movie youngsters are planning a trip to an isolated vacation home in the forest. The group includes the jock Curt (Chris Hemsworth, "Thor," although this movie was made before that one), his partygirl, Jules (Anna Hutchison, "Go Girls" TV series), brainiac Holden (Jesse Williams, "Grey's Anatomy" TV series), good girl Dana (Kristen Connolly, "The Good Wife" TV series) and the stoner fifth-wheel, Marty (Fran Kranz, "Donnie Darko," "Training Day," "Diary Of a Wimpy Kid: Roddrick Rules").

It's more than obvious that the couples will hook up while the philosophizing sad-sack Marty will be alone with his thoughts, but he nevertheless tags along with the gang in a huge RV, even when things begin to get decidedly creepy.

For instance, at what appears to be an abandoned gas station, a leathery attendant, Mordaci (Tim De Zarn, "Live Free Or Die Hard," "The Artist"), starts to angrily spout ominous warnings about their destination, even calling Jules a "whore."

The kids, however, ignore the weirdo and proceed to the desolate domicile, which looks like the Munsters' summer home on the outside, but seems to be cozy and well-kept inside. A few introductory scenes of each character, some alcohol and drug use, as well as a game of truth or dare takes place before the fun really kicks off, with terrifying creatures soon surrounding the cabin.

All the while, for some reason, the entire event is being observed by scientists, including Sitterson (Jenkins), Hadley (Whitford) and military bodyguard, Truman (Brian White, "The Game Plan," "12 Rounds"). Is it some kind of mind or behavior control experiment? Is it an elaborate government spy operation? Is it a candid reality television show?

Of course, I will not reveal the secret, suffice to write, though, it comes out of left field and will no doubt leave many viewers shocked and pleasantly surprised at the outcome. And even though the picture has been in the can for more than three years, it was a matter of getting money for distribution, NOT because it was a poison project.

The inclusion of Jenkins and Whitford, as previously mentioned, is a nice touch and their work together adds a great comedic element to the proceedings (an even more recognizable celebrity appears in a late cameo). And, the young actors, for the most part do very well, including Franz, who steals every scene he is in as the bumbling pothead who begins to suspect the worst.

Even the pre-"Thor" Hemsdale and Williams, and the slutty Hutchison, do fine in what little is given them. The only negative I can write about the production is the performance of the lead actress Connelly, who, sadly, cannot convince anyone that she is in real danger or convey a sense of terror that would have certainly overcome anyone else.

That being written, though, "Cabin In the Woods" is quite entertaining and with several curves before the conclusion, a great way to spend a few hours at the cinema — something you cannot say a lot about most of the movies showing these days.

title: If you love horror movie this is one you need to see.
review:
This movie was fantastic. at first it took awhile for me to get over the whole "what the hell am I watching", feeling but by the end I loved it. This movie, I would describe as the twisted cousin of the evil dead series. I say this because I've never laughed or yelled at the screen as much as I did while watching this.

Whoever wrote this had to have though hey lets watch a lot of horror movies while doing acid. This movie in my opinion was not advertised properly, from the trailer you would imagine that this was just a run of the mill slasher flick. this movie is an ode to ever horror movie that came before, with the same atmosphere that those 70s midnight showing movies use to have.

straight off the bat the movie tries to mixed it up with the characters making the sporty guy smart making the slutty one a caring nurse in training, and they actually pulled it off. I can say I was really rooting for these kids to live unlike all the other slashers where I can't wait to see how they die. by the time these kids make it to the basement, that is filled with junk that came straight from over a dozen famous horror movies that I notices, I was screaming at the screen have you never seen, Hellraiser, Evil Dead, or a Jason movie in your life. a real surprise was the stoner character in this movie who has been smoking pot from the beginning and has basically figured out everything thats going on thanks to a small dose of paranoia. If you liked Zombieland, Evil Dead , Drag me to Hell this is your movie, not to say that it's not a damn good horror movie with buckets of gore at every turn, but its was just so much fun to watch.

title: An absolute hoot
review:
Two girls and three guys go off in a van to spend a weekend in a remote cabin in the woods. After an encounter with a sinister man at a filling station, they eventually arrive at the run down cabin, and start behaving in the ways in which young people in remote cabins are accustomed to behave. But what are those men in white coats up to?

Drew Goddard's first movie as director (co-written with Joss Whedon) tells us, before we sit down to watch it, that it is playing with a sub-genre of the horror movie, and that it wants us to know this right from the start. And what follows is as playful as the title. We get our fair share of cabin in the woods shenanigans, but we get a heck of a lot else, too. And I'm not going to say anything about them, because this movie has surprises up its sleeve.

It also has a very good script, with some laugh out loud moments. I thoroughly enjoyed every second of it.

title: It's a good movie... if you wanna be confused for 90% of it
review: How this movie got such a high rating is beyond me. Really, it's so bad. I don't understand how it got a 7/10 there were some funny parts, but that's it. I had no idea what was going on for the first hour of the movie. And when I finally did understand what was happening I realized how bad it is. And what exactly was the point of that man at the gas station, I--

title: Just no.
review: Don't waste your time. The story was the worst. I am getting so sick and tired of the lack of creativity in the movie industry theese days. I am very much aware of the fact that my standards in regards to film are high but I doubt that I am the only inte who had difficulties watching the movie.

title: Best Horror Film Yet!!!
review:
When I watch the trailer, I thought the film is bad. I was wrong. When I watch it, it was very awesome and creative. It's really rare for a horror film. This is the list of "why I like this film": 1. The characters are tough!!! The main characters are stabbed, got beaten brutally, bitten by a monster and got caught by a swinging bear trap and still alive.

2. Many monsters are shown in the last 20-25 minutes of the film. Yes, there are. It has werewolf, giant vampire bat, giant snake, zombies, clowns and many more. We just don't know what it is. We just see the trailer, showing the Buckners (the killer zombies) and the killers wearing a mask.

3. There's a lot of stories.

Story #1: Five friends go to the cabin and have fun, but got attacked by a family of killer zombies.

Story #2: Facility members planned all of this killings for a ritual to the Ancient Ones, so that the world will not end.

Story #3: Two of the friends survived and go to the facility, then, releasing the monsters, causing a gruesome massacre to the members.

Story #4: The two met the Director and the ritual needs the following kinds of persons: A wh*re (Jules), an athlete (Curt), a scholar (Holden), a fool (Marty) and a virgin (Dana).

4. Most of all, the film has laughs throughout and most of the violence and gore are after the first 40 minutes.

title: bad
review: whoever thought this movie was good was probably as high as Marty (the stoner kid in the movie). I was bored watching this and didn't understand it. I love horror movies and this was just bad. It would be better if it was thought out more. I kinda liked the concept, it was different. It was still just bad. Definitely would not recommend anyone to watch this. The start of the movie makes you wonder if you are even watching the correct movie, i had started this movie a couple of months ago but turned it off since i was confused. Some of the monsters were pretty cool. I didn't like how they portrayed the unicorn as a bad character, that saddened me. Sorry, i don't know what else to write, damn thing is making me write 10 lines worth, but i just wanted to get to the point, since there is not much to say about this movie other than it being awful, and a waste of time to watch. I would rather watch paint dry.

title: Cult classic!
review:
This movie has to be one of the best Horror/Comedy movies i've ever seen. However, this isn't your "typical" Horror movie.

Whenever I saw previews for The Cabin in the Woods, I would shudder in a tiny bit of fear AKA I needed to go see this movie ASAP. It looked like a fairly typical horror film (which I love), but boy was I wrong. This movie was far from typical.

Five friends — Dana (Kristen Connolly), Curt (Chris Hemsworth), Jules (Anna Hutchison), Marty (Fran Kranz), and Holden (Jesse Williams) — take a trip to a cabin in the woods (surprised, right?). It doesn't take too long for the fivesome's mini vacation to be rudely, and might I add violently, interrupted. By who (and/or what)? Why? You most definitely need to find out for yourself. You won't be disappointed, I promise.

I loved The Cabin in the Woods. It was so different from anything I've ever seen. I thought it was the perfect mix of horror and comedy. Yup, that's right it was funny (and not in a this-acting-is-so-bad kind of way). The movie subtly pokes fun at the corniness you find in some most horror films (not to the point of a spoof like Scary Movie though) and I thought it was hilarious. There would be intermittent jabs at the right moments when you'd normally be thinking to yourself: "Oh, how typical" Nothing normal or typical about this movie though (and I mean that in the best way possible). While I'm emphasizing the movie's humor, I don't want to desensitize its horrifying moments (because believe me, there were quite a handful). I was very much on the edge of my seat at times, wanting to watch the movie through my fingers (I didn't though).

I don't want to say too much about the storyline, but I was completely thrown for a loop (from the very beginning to the absolute end). The trailers certainly don't give any hints as to what's really behind this movie, which I absolutely love. I mean, the movie was directed by Drew Goddard, the writer for Cloverfield (another great movie), so I shouldn't have expected anything less. Keep 'em coming, Goddard (apparently I'm a fan).

Acting-wise, I think everyone did great a job. Everyone played their stereotypical horror film roles to a T, whether it was the jock, the dumb blond, the virgin, the pothead, etc. The actors did well when it came time to fear for their lives, but they also did well when they needed to poke fun at their own characters in funny, not corny way. I think my favorite character was Marty, who played the stoner. He certainly provided plenty (sometimes much-needed) comic relief with his drugged up, philosophical rants.

Overall, I give The Cabin in the Woods I'm gonna do it 5/5 stars. This movie kept me engaged the entire time (whether it was through fear and/or laughing) and I couldn't stop raving about it after I left the theater. This will definitely be a movie I'll be adding to my DVD collection.

title: First Horror Movie to Surprise Me !
review:
I don't know where to start, this movie was great.

I was not expecting that and I still cannot believe the director attempted something like this. This is a movie that puts all the horror genre upside down.

So when I read bad reviews with stuff like that : "of course, a young bunch of teenagers (sexy ones) get into the woods and there it begins.. they start dying... Wow... never happened before.."

Well man, you went full retard. You understood just about nothing about it. Even the movie poster tells you "You think you know the story ? Think again"...

This is what I said to my friend : This is not a movie, this is, by itself, the backstage of every single horror movie ever made. Think about any horror flick, and the Cabin in the Woods will explain the "why" and "how". Makes you all see it differently.

So in the end, this was extremely fun to watch. Never got bored. One of the best movie I have seen so far. I can only recommend it.

title: Amazing, Original, Brilliant!
review:
This is my first review on this site - I registered especially to write this about this particular movie and after seeing all the hate reviews. IMO, this movie was OUTSTANDING! It's brilliant and hilarious! It's everything you could expect from Joss Wheddon and much more! And the reviews actually prove it, even the negative ones. Those who gave only 1 star never understood what was going on at all and what the whole point was.

All in all, the most important thing is this - this is not a horror movie. If you expect to see an ordinary horror movie with a tiny twist to make it different and to fit the advertisement, correct your expectations, because you're going to be disappointed. If you expect horror to be mixed with comedy like many other movies has done, okay, you're on the right track, but still very far from the truth.

This movie is completely different. It's horror, mixed with comedy, mixed with scifi, mixed with mystery, mixed with epic movies. And I don't mean it's one of those mish-mashes that don't work at all - everything here fits in its rightful place to deliver an outstanding genre-bending experience! Also, make sure you are a fan of at least a few TV shows. If you don't watch TV and you only watch movies, than this won't be for you. People doing movies approach things much differently than people doing TV shows. So if you like characters that you don't care about because you don't meet for more than 2 hours, if you don't like too many ideas and jokes in one place because it's too complicated for your brain, if not top-level CGI is enough to ruin everything for you, don't watch this.

I'm deliberately not commenting on anything from the plot, because this would be a spoiler. The trailers gave enough spoilers already, that and the not top-level CGI are the only negative sides of this movie. But they are not that important at all to take away even 1 star from my rating! I'm giving all 10 with a clear conscience.

Now, abstract yourself from all expectations you have and start watching this movie with an open mind. I'm sure it will help you view it in a much better light, but only of course if you're into smarter stuff - if you prefer dumber movies where everything is clear and obvious even that won't help.

title: Horrible Horror
review: The plot is original. The acting is not THAT BAD. What is bad is labeling this movie as horror. There was absolutely no horror in it.Throwing 500 monsters in a shot is not horrible.It's just stupid. And as for the reviews that gave it an almost 10 score for being a great HORROR movie...you guys really don't know what the horror genre is all about. I'm almost guessing you're all 12-15 years old. Because this movie is a shadow of what "horror" movies are about. The sci-fi label and comedy part are OK. The movie was funny.But labeling it as horror ruined it somewhere in the middle when it finally hits you:"i'm not going to see horror...this is a movie based on the reality show craze we've been in for the past few years". And you only watch it to the end because you're wondering who the audience is...vampires...freaking mummies...no...the end is even more stupid :) Voting 1 because it's not horror.And giving bad horror movies good ratings will result in more bad horror movies. No thank you.

title: The Cabin in the Woods (2011)
review: To tell you what this film is about is to spoil it. Basically we have 5 college kids go to a cabin in the woods. You can guess where it will go from there, but there is a side story that hints at something strange and new. The Cabin In The Woods is a perfect deconstruction of the predictability of horror and actually gives an explanation as to why the genre is so predictable. The characters are excellent with each one being a real human being and not just a cliché. The humour is so well written I was in hysterics. Jenkins and Whitford make an excellent double act that I want to see more of. The effects, gore, action were all spot on and I could just gush continuously about how awesome that end was. All I'll say is that I had massive expectations and knew more than I wanted to about the film, and I was still constantly surprised and wowed every few minutes.

title: Horror-Roller-Coaster Ride!
review:
This is definitely not some average horror flick. Watching this movie is like riding a horror-roller-coaster. Two third of the movie is almost like another slasher movies, but with more entertaining humor, I have some LOL moments at the time. But the last half hour of the movie, when Marty & Dana goes deep in the control room head quarter, the ride is getting faster and faster. With all of the evil creatures, ghosts & goblins running around, I was speechless. This is the only movie that i've seen where all kinds of evil creatures perform such an amazing orchestra of destruction. really classy & brilliant! And when the ending where Dana said she was sorry for almost shooting Marty, than humanity restored (and than vanished after that of course....) I must give credit to all of the actors, especially Fran Kranz , he fits right in with the character Marty. Another credit goes to the team in the control room, they somehow give a cheerful color for this dark movie. If you're a fan of horror movie, you MUST NOT miss this movie! You'll have a lot of good times. well, I did.

For This amazing horror-roller-coaster ride, I give a verdict of: 9/10

title: Thanks Josh Whedon... A work of Sheer Genius!
review: I will keep it short because the less you know about this film, the better it will be. How refreshing to watch an horror movie that doesn't fall into the same trap that most do these days? That trap of starting out with a good idea that ultimately falls flat on its face or just runs out of steam towards the end. To many horror flicks fall into this trap and this is were 'Cabin in the Woods' excels and turns the genre on its head. It starts out like the most boring, clichéd, run-of-the-mill story 'five teens head out for a weekend at a run down log cabin' ...Yawn, but thats exactly what Josh Whedon the director wants you to think. You cant really say to much without spoiling it but I will just say, if you like horror movies that keep you on the edge of your seat, by the end of this movie you will have discovered how many 'edges' your seat can actually have! An absolutely outstanding movie that will change the genre for good, I hope. (I cant wait to watch it again with a friend who doesn't know what is going to unfold before his eyes) I cant believe all the negative comments this movie receives on IMDb. To describe this movie in a sentence, I would say... 'Cabin in the Woods is The Inception of the horror genre' and the absolute saviour of horror movies in general.

title: Loved the film
review: I am a film lover. I watch every thing especially horror films. I have scene them all.Loved the new Friday the 13th btw. But this film took you in directions you NEVER expected. I mean I didn't know what was going on this the very last 10% of the film. I just wish they had left it open for another. Maybe they can do something. Just wow the way they did this is great. Only thing that sucks is having to write 10 lines here to do a review so sorry for the next lines of no info even though the movie rocked. The movie was terrific go see it go rent it go download it. title: My Whole Life Is A Complete Lie!!!
review:
This will be the first movie review I write, and I only do so simply because I feel that this movie deserves as many accolades it can get. Especially since it was begrudgingly given cinema screen time by the distributors, who really wanted it to go straight to DVD. In fact, the distributors were so reluctant, that they gave it permission to air at ONLY one cinema in Melbourne, which is ridiculous! We had to drive an hour to get to that one cinema.

I love watching movies, and even more so, I love horror movies. I live in hope of being able to watch a decent horror movie, but these moments are far and few in between. I think the last time I was scared in a movie would have been when we went to an international film festival and saw Ringu. And so I was super excited to find out that Joss Whedon made a horror movie.

Up front, I will confess, I am a HUGE Joss Whedon fan so I probably do have a certain bias. However, even if Joss had no part in it, I would have still loved this movie to death! It has one of the most creative and imaginative plots I have seen in a very long, long time.

This movie takes all those typical horror movie clichés, that we are all familiar with (teens, alcohol, drugs, creepy old guy, cabin, woods, etc) and all the horror movie rules we are aware of (don't walk backwards, don't separate from the group, etc) and makes you comfortable, thinking you know exactly where it's going, because you've seen it all before, right? WRONG!!! What it actually does, is make you reference and question ever other horror movie you've ever seen, and wonder if this is what was actually happening in the background!

I actually did say out loud "My whole life is a complete lie ...!" as the story unfolded before my eyes. There was no point in time where I was not surprised, and I am a horror movie veteran.

It has every single imaginable horror in it, all your favourite beasties, the old and new, and yet, despite the terrible things that are happening to poor hapless humans, Joss and Drew are still able to bring levity to any situation and make you laugh unexpectedly.

HOWEVER, herein lies the problem - I don't think that this should actually be classified as a "horror" move. When asked about the movie, I really struggled to describe it as a horror move, because it wasn't really about the horror, just as Zombieland wasn't really about the zombies. Yeah, there's gore, and blood, and stabbing, and monsters, but that's all circumstantial. I think this is where people have been misled and this is probably why there are so many 1-star angry ratings.

Personally, I could have easily given it 10 out of 10 stars, but to be fair, to balance out my undying devotion for anything from the Whedonverse, I felt I had to deduct one star.

title: Produced By Fans, For Fans
review:
The Cabin in the Woods isn't one of the best horror films you'll ever see, but there aren't many genre films that are more novel. There are any number of horror movies that are undeniably scarier, or more insightful, or better directed, but at least compared to other films from the last ten years or so, probably none that are more original.

Ironically, the film's originality actually derives from its awareness of horror stereotypes and its willingness to play around with them. Anyone who has watched a handful of horror films—especially so-called Slasher movies—is familiar with these stereotypes, and will probably bring certain expectations into the cinema with them to watch The Cabin in the Woods. But even as it celebrates these stereotypes, the script (by genre favorites Drew Goddard and Joss Whedon) uses them to invert the audience's experience. Everything from the cast of characters to the jump scares to the setting and expected resolution are played according to formula—to a point. But then the formula is slowly shot to pieces, exposing several unexpected subplots that turn a very conventional horror movie into something very unique indeed.

The less one knows about the plot going in the better, so I won't say anything more about the script. The direction and production values are, however, excellent, and the cast (which includes Kristen Connolly, Anne Hutchison, and Chris Hemsworth) is wonderful, and the actors all totally sell out for their roles. The result is that characters that fit all the horror archetypes—the Jock, the Bad Girl, the Nerd, etc—are also believable and distinct individuals with their own personalities. Connolly is especially noteworthy in her portrayal of Dana, the obvious Final Girl, and this could easily be a breakout role for her.

None of which is to say that The Cabin in the Woods is perfect. The big reveal is a shocker but also undercuts any underlying morality the film might pretend to have, if it were trying to do anything but put a novel twist on tired conventions. The dialogue is sometimes a bit too much "on the nose," as though Whedon and Goddard didn't always know when to let a train of thought go while they were typing the screenplay. And while the trailer doesn't really indicate it, the film is as much a comedy as it is horror, and the transition between the two emotional highs isn't always seamless.

But fans of the horror genre will want to see The Cabin the Woods no matter its weaknesses, because the film is, if nothing else, a strikingly original reinterpretation of a formula that badly needed it. Time will tell if The Cabin in the Woods is really the best horror movie of 2012, but it will almost certainly reign as the year's most unique genre entry.

title: Do Not Watch If You Are Stupid
review:
**THIS REVIEW CONTAINS A LOT OF SPOILERS, AND QUICKLY.** A quick note to address the oft-repeated criticism throughout these reviews: Don't watch movies smarter than you.

"I don't understand why they showed those Japanese Girls! This movie was stupid!" "Why were they controlling those teens? I don't get it!" "Why did they all need to die slowly and horribly? It's so stupid!" Sorry, a movie doesn't suck because you weren't smart enough to get it. If you think the acting was amateurish, or the plot was full of holes, or the director made a mess of things, or the lighting sucked, or any criticism of the actual MOVIE, then good on you. You're a discriminating consumer who knows what (s)he wants. On the other hand, if you didn't "get" the movie and didn't understand what was going on, that's more a comment about you than this movie. This wasn't The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari, people. It was a completely comprehensible movie that required only a few watts of brainpower to follow.

On to the review: The Cabin in the Woods gets 9 stars because I don't like horror movies. Yes, it is. Stop saying it isn't. This movie is the definition of horror movies. Isolated locale, terrified victims being killed in gruesome ways, blood and gore, zombies and sharp, stabby things, nubile teens and monsters - yep, it's a horror movie. Joss Whedon style.

What's Whedon style? The curveball, ho-hum office banter beginning that only makes sense later. "I'm still on speakerphone." Lots of in-jokes for horror fans. A kick-ass hot girl who doesn't know the meaning of the words, "Just show us your boobs and die, like you're supposed to in a horror movie." And a story that is working on multiple levels simultaneously.

Example? When the bird hits the force field as the camper crosses the threshold, it's saying something. You know immediately the teens are trapped. You know this isn't just about some lunatic with a chainsaw or an ancient curse. Joss's fans just got a wink, letting them know something Whedon this way comes. And you just KNOW one of those teens is gonna follow the birdie. One quick zap, and it's chock full of exposition, foreboding, 'hint, hint' and humor, and a quick hello from an artist to his fans.

The Cabin in the Woods works because there are enough layers to please almost everyone - plenty of slice and dice for the gore fans, impish humor of the camp fans, unnameable horrors for the Lovecraft fans, hot girls and cheesecake for the 14 year olds who sneaked in - and they never bog the movie down. It moves along, escalating nicely, the progression logical in hindsight and plenty creepy for the nonce.

The story is about the answer many viewers of horror movies never receive to their oft-asked question: "Yes, but WHY?" The answer: Because if it doesn't go down exactly like horror movies should, the world will end. A few die so many may live. Not especially original, but this is Hollywood and this is horror: nothing is original anymore.

The cast is great, with Kristen Connolly a perfect Whedon girl: sweet, sexy, tough, intelligent, "Excuse me? WHO did you just call an ingénue?!" She fights even when she's losing badly and manages to keep winning the ultimate prize: survival. Whedon alum Fran Kranz as the philosophically conspiracy-minded stoner hits all the right comic relief notes, acting as the audience's avatar many times. Anna Hutchinson, Chris Hemsworth, and Jesse Williams fill out the soon-to-be-dead list of normal, organic roles nicely. There isn't a "No one would tolerate this asshole for five seconds in real life" in the bunch. They're normal, mundane, run-of-the-mill. They're us, which adds a little sympathetic chill to their deaths.

The villains in the movie aren't the monsters, or the teens, or vice (or something similarly corny). In truth, the villains are us, the people in the chairs, watching the spectacle. We are represented by the puppet masters in their enclave, manipulating the environment to turn the screws and up the heat. They've lost whatever it is that would fill a body with outrage over the things they're doing - even to save the world - and it's all just a day at the office to them.

It is to these people Whedon and Goddard are their cruelest. The REAL horror and splatter and viscera starts at the end, the payoff to all the buildup we've been watching, an orgy of monsters rampaging through the enclave, giving the bad guys their comeuppance. It's the catharsis we've been craving, the once-removed self-flagellation for having been spectators to this horrible tableau, purifying the wicked in blood and death, restoring balance - for the scant amount of time remaining for there to be a world where balance matters.

And here's the kicker: you don't even have to "get" all that to enjoy this movie. You can simply root for the good guys to survive and the bad guys to get theirs; you'll get satisfaction with both. That's the fun of Joss Whedon; he's never up his own ass with his cleverness. There's always enough to enjoy even if you don't want to join his hipper-than-hippos club.

But you do have to be minimally intelligent. Despite what one hater (who clearly just wants to rebel against 'whatever') thinks, this is not Scary Movie. It's Evil Dead on meth and peyote.

title: 1/2 old horror flick +1/2 new treatment = Rodriguez style!
review:
Are you a guy who likes old school horror movie and want to take out a girl who likes the over-the-top-close-to-comedy horror? Well, if so, you got a date!

If at the beginning we're not sure about the mix of old fashion and the «modern-and-digital» touch, the outcome is good enough to support expectations.

Somehow in the spirit of reality show (I could not stop myself thinking about Truman show all the movie long), the least we can say is this is in the taste of the day. The old horror elements are well done despite the fact that some of the intense scenes (the fights with the zombies, for instance) are a bit too shaky (read here : we don't see clearly and the sound is in a «patchingwork» use).

The last third of the movie takes a surprising turn and the refreshing effect of all of it worth the time if not the patience (I say that because after a while in the wood, you may feel that the movie tramples but what happen next makes you forgot (and forgive) about). And what to say about the orgy (not sexually) of freaky monsters (I don't want to say too much, just in case...).

At the risk to repeat what I mentioned in the summary, it is in the Rodriguez style. Maybe a bit less spicy than Planet Terror but how far better that Machete! Horror fans, it's for you!

title: Best movie i watched on cinema lately.
review: I won't say much, but just this. You can't call yourself a horror movie fan and not liking -if not loving- this movie. Only if you just started watching horror movies and you know s**t. And for all those of you who don't know it, there IS actually a genre called horror comedy. And i thought only the Greek audience was that narrow-minded. As for the 3rd and final act of the film, it's really WOW. I hope you 'll be able to admire it and not be like 'what the hell is that incoherent piece of c**p'. Cause that incoherent piece of c**p will be you. Last GREAT final act in a horror movie i can remember is the party in Braindead. This comes pretty close. (If not surpasses it).

title: Good fun comedy horror film with a strong inventive twist. This film is very meta in a good way.
review:
I had heard some good rumors about this film but went in to the cinema pretty unaware of the films plot. I had watched the trailer before viewing the film and like most people felt it gave away too much up front. Fear not the trailer gives away only one real twist of the film.

On to the movie itself. People in the woods and sh*t starts to go wrong. Thats about all you need to know about the film, and that it is more of a comedy than a straight up horror film. If you go in wanting to be scared then you could come away disappointed. However If you are a fan of the horror/comedy genre then this film is for you.

The acting is average, but a good kind of average. The film relies more on humor, premise and visuals over straight up acting. The actors do a good job of making their characters likable to the audience which keeps you invested long into the second act where the big twist really comes to the fore. Fran Kranz deserves mention as the funniest and best realized of the characters though this is probably due more to how he was written than anything else. Also quick nod to Anna Hutchison for a fun make out scene.

The films visuals are pretty good for a 30 million dollar budget but there are a few effects that could have been beefed up a bit. The soundtrack didn't leave much of an impression but it served it purpose. The films pacing is good through out even if it does lose itself a little at the end of the film. Which if I did have any complaints that would be it, the ending isn't bad it is just not as good as the lead up to it.

To conclude "The cabin in the woods" is a fun film. Not the best horror or comedy film you will see this year but certainly inventive and well executed. In the congested horror genre that too often relies of reusing old material well past the sale by date "The Cabin in the woods" feels new and fresh, a real treat for fans of the genre.

title: Must see!!!
review:
Joss Whedon created my favorite television show of all time: BUFFY THE VAMPIRE SLAYER. Tired of seeing the helpless blonde "cheerleader" character be killed off first in so many horror films, he turned the genre on its head. Now it was the blonde cheerleader who was doing the stalking, killing and hunting, but for the good guys. With the new film THE CABIN IN THE WOODS with BUFFY alumnus Drew Goddard, Whedon once again takes an old and tired genre and injects some life into it. The best way to describe THE CABIN IN THE WOODS is to say that it is a horror movie about horror movies. This is Whedon's love/hate letter to the horror genre.

Without giving away the spoilerish parts of the plot, I'll simply say that it involves five friends who fit the horror movie stereotype (Jock, Slut, Stoner, Nerd, Virgin) who go to a – you got it – cabin in the woods. They want to party of course, get away from it all, "off the grid" as one character points out. The trouble is, it's never really a good idea to go to a cabin in the woods. If the horror genre has taught us anything, it's to stay away from these places. To be honest, the less you know about this film, the better. The trailer is all about the fact that you "think you know the story" and that's exactly what this film is about, our preconceived notions, which is where Whedon and Goddard have their fun with us.

Fans of BUFFY and ANGEL will get a real kick out of this flick. Not only do characters from the Whedonverse show up (YAY for Fred and Andrew) but the overall tone of the film feels like it could be lifted right from the show. Of course, in saying that, I feel like I'm saying too much, so let's move on shall we?

THE CABIN IN THE WOODS is one hell of a fun movie. The last time I had this much fun was with GRINDHOUSE, which was just as off the wall and entertaining as this one. That film was a hard one to sell, and I have the sad feeling that CABIN will be too. I can only hope that it does well, because the film deserves an audience and horror fans will certainly get a kick out of it. It's the best damn horror film to come out since Neil Marshall's THE DESCENT.

To say it's all horror would be an understatement because the film is hilarious. Whedon and Goddard perfectly blend horror and comedy, which is usually a tricky balance, but these two guys worked on Buffy, which was a balancing act of genres itself. Taking the clichéd aspects of every horror film and throwing it up on the screen for us in a brilliant and deconstructing manner, we have a film that isn't afraid to laugh at itself. Every stupid character mistake in horror films is used to great effect here. Whedon and Goddard give purpose to why these things happen in the genre we all love to hate sometimes.

Richard Jenkins and Bradley Whitford have great chemistry together and steal every scene they're in. Watching these two gave a different aspect to what we would expect from a cabin in the woods flick. The young actors on the screen all fit their roles well; we even get a chance to see a Thor-less Chris Hemsworth. In most films of this type, I'm rooting for the Freddy Kruegers or the Michael Myers of the slasher world, but here I was actually rooting for the victims. None of them are annoying, which is refreshing.

There are more hilarious moments than scary ones, if I had to pick a side of the fence to fall on. I'm dying to talk about them, but doing so would ruin the experience for those reading. Seriously, go in knowing as little as possible. The film isn't afraid to show where it grabs its inspiration. THE EVIL DEAD is heavily referenced here, as are some other notable horror flicks. That's not to say that Cabin is in the shadows of other films, it stands on its own and without a doubt makes its mark on the horror genre. It will be hard for people to watch future teen horror flicks and not have CABIN pop up in the back of their heads.

THE CABIN IN THE WOODS is one of a kind. People have been comparing it to SCREAM, in the sense that it's very self-aware and pumps life into a tiresome genre. I will agree with those statements, but don't expect people to go where this film went. It's too unique and bizarre for people to even try. From the moment the title card appears on the screen, you should know what type of movie you're about to see. I had a big grin on my face throughout the entire thing and it's safe to say that this is definitely in my top ten of the year. As a fan of the horror genre, I'm happy to say that THE CABIN IN THE WOODS has restored my faith. We have a film here that is not afraid to tell you what it thinks of horror movies, what's right with them, what's wrong with them and more importantly, why we love them.

– Matt Layden

This review first appeared in Geek Speak Magazine - www.geekspeakmagazine.com

title: Fun, blood splattered thrill ride.
review:
When I first saw the trailer I thought "Oh... one of these... for the millionth time." Group-o-"teens" headed to a creepy cabin where they will be slaughtered one by one like we've all seen - thanks 90s teenie bopper slasher flicks. But alas, I was wrong.

I distinctly remember a point in the theater where my mouth was hanging open just from the sheer madness on the screen unfolding in front of me.

This movie was very entertaining. The story was completely wacky and original and that's what I needed. We are constantly slammed with sub par remakes every year, I was doubting there were any creative juices still flowing in the horror movie industry, but this film stands out.

They raised the bar are crazy and I loved it.

title: Whedony goodness!
review:
It's the Dollhouse run by Wolfram and Hart.

And it's glorious!

I've noticed the only people who have disliked this movie are the ones who went in expecting a "horror" movie.

It's a Whedonverse movie. Sci-fi/fantasy with lots of satire and social commentary.

People keep complaining about the ending but I honestly don't see any other way it could have ended without being anticlimactic and cliché.

This will be a fun one to re-watch with a room full of first time viewers.

title: A smart, funny, scary, and gory movie
review: I just saw this film today and oh my god I just loved it. This film kept me on the edge of my seat almost the entire time. This is one of the creepiest films I have seen since silent hill. This is also one of the most original horror films I have seen in a long time. The storyline was excellent, the script was well thought out and there was enough blood and gore to make me cringe. If you are looking for a great horror comedy film then go see Cabin in the woods. This film is an absolute adrenaline rush. This movie is capable of being funny scary and gory all at the same time. Go and see this film and I promise you will not be disappointed. highly recommended.

title: 'The Cabin in the Woods' Meets Your Expectations, Then Destroys Them
review:
The horror genre clings onto and feeds off of audience expectations. From a fan perspective, horror-lovers tend to flock to films that appear as if they will evoke the feelings of previous successes, even to the point of supporting blatant mimicry. From a filmmaking perspective, a horror director's go-to card is expectation—the audience recognizing those classic audio and visual clues that create the anticipation of a scare.

The entire horror genre is built on the foundation of what we think will happen, so when "The Cabin in the Woods" comes along and utilizes these expectations while also blowing the roof completely off them, it makes for a wildly entertaining success.

Sure, some folks will want a run-of-the-mill "cabin in the woods" story, the one we've seen a thousand times thanks to paragons "Friday the 13th" and "The Evil Dead" among others. "The Cabin in the Woods" might let down those purists who rank the scare factor as top priority, but for fans of parody and satire, this is a must-see.

The minds behind the film suggest a certain intelligence you won't find in horror offerings from amateurs. Drew Goddard, writer of "Cloverfield" and on TV's "Lost," and Joss Whedon, one of the most revered names in geek culture, team up on a script that delivers a great deal of wit and at the same time a strong mystery, a combination that makes for an irrepressibly exciting movie.

"The Cabin in the Woods" requires a certain amount of aversion to spoilers in order to be fully enjoyed, though so many unsuspected twists crop up that a few details won't actually ruin anything. Essentially, five college kids head to a remote cabin for the weekend and predictably ignore some tell-tale signs that something's amiss. The catch is that despite seeing this setup before, we as an audience don't even quite know what's going on this time around. The fact that the film doesn't open on a cabin, woods, or college kids is your first hint.

Perhaps the biggest surprise has nothing do with the plot: the young protagonists are somewhat likable and the actors portraying them have a good deal of talent. Nearly everyone will recognize Chris Hemsworth (Thor himself) as Curt, but the highlights are unknowns Kristen Connolly and Fran Kranz as Dana and Marty, one an attractive bookworm and the other a clever stoner. The characters fit your horror stereotypes, but each with a bit of a twist that makes them more respectable. Even the "dumb blonde" (Anna Hutchison) isn't that dumb as she cares about her friends. Heck, the fact that these five would all be friends is kind of a jab at stereotypes.

Strong writing reinforces the fact that these are more developed characters and shows Goddard and Whedon recognize that even though the goal is to turn the genre upside down, their film still needs to do the things good horror films do right in order to succeed.

Without giving anything away, the central idea behind the movie is basically to give a mythology to a typical horror story motif such as the cabin in the woods, to weave it together with a science-fiction yarn that allows us to look at the genre both with humor and a greater reverence.

"The Cabin in the Woods" provides pure entertainment of a brilliant sort, an absolute rarity in any genre, let alone horror. With some pitch-perfect casting in roles best kept a secret, Goddard and Whedon sell their twist with great effectiveness. In hindsight, the whole operation could have backfired had there been just the slightest reason not to stay interested or care about the characters.

Anyone with a keen eye for or love of satire and a familiarity with the horror offerings being played off of will find themselves on the exact same page as Goddard throughout the film. Consequently, these folks will simply love "The Cabin in the Woods." It's one thing to poke fun at a genre—anyone can do that, especially in horror. This movie does it without flopping into silly mindless spoof territory, instead entertaining us exactly as a traditional horror riff would.

Although you won't see critical accolades because genre films get no love, "The Cabin in the Woods" will get its due when it appears on countless Best of 2012 lists—unless more and more 2012 movies that aren't supposed to be this good soar beyond expectations.

~Steven C

Thanks for reading! Check out moviemusereviews.com

title: Worst movie of all time
review: I literally hated this movie so much I had to come here and write a review. IMDb you fail... why do you say this movie has over a 7 star rating? I never write reviews.. so the fact that I am right now says a lot. Don't watch this repugnant movie. You'll be confused until nearly the end and then when it does make sense, you'll be so mad you spent that much time watching it to find out. The silly attempts at humor are sad. The crazy attempt at scary things is plain sad.... The attempt at the animation and the monsters are very very sad. lol. It literally looks like they almost copied Hunger games idea but made it way worse by turning it into a really bad horror/comedy/thriller.

title: By far the worst movie I have ever seen hands down!!!!
review: I feel bad giving this morning a 1 that is way to high a mark. Do not waste your money or your time one this movie their are not enough words to describe how terrible it is!!! I honestly don't know how it ever got financed let alone filmed and marketed! I'm a movie buff I watch movies all the time and I have to say that this movie is my #1 pick for worst movie ever! The plot is terrible the acting is horrible and more likely than not you will not even see the ending because the whole thing is so silly. It's one of those movies where the only reason you continue to watch it is because you keep encouraging yourself that it is going to get better....take it from me it doesn't!!! If you decided to rent it anyway don't blame me I tried to warn you.

title: Fantastic Send-Up of All Things Horror
review:
I suppose I shouldn't be surprised at the negative reviews, but I am. As one well-known critic so aptly described it, this film is a "final exam for fanboys." Some reviewers seem to have failed the test. "Am I missing something here??" Yes. Yes you are.

Subtext, folks. An item that seems to be vacant from modern-day slasher flicks (re: torture porn), and Joss and Drew know it. That's why the layers to this movie run so deep. And that's why there are so many low ratings, because those horrible movies have left our expectations so low that fans have been trained to look only at the surface level. Gore. Screams. Pain. Torture. Psychopaths. No motivation besides sheer insanity.

What about the puppeteers pulling the strings? How much of this is absolutely scripted before the writer even sits down with the pen? How much control do the writers actually have? Is it possible to do something completely new, or is everything written already? I'll say it again: subtext, folks.

I'm sad for this movie. Because there is so much that can't be given away, the marketing department was left with very little to sell this movie. People weren't sure what to expect when they came in. I like to think that many people like me expected nothing but the unexpected. Sadly, I now honestly believe that many a fanboy came into the theater to see yet another horribly acted generic cabin in the woods story and were left sorely disappointed when the true intent of the film went over their heads. They got a cheesy version of what they paid for, but missed the point: the bad part of it was done that way intentionally. This is Joss Whedon. You should know better by now.

Look deeper. See this film for what it is: pure genius.

title: Hmmmmm...
review:
Hmmmmmm...what do I say about Cabin? Is it the most brilliant horror movie ever made? No. Is it the worst trash ever? No. So what is it?

It's a twist of a script that doesn't just explain itself from the beginning. Thats why the reviews are so mixed. If you expected and enjoyed straightforward movies like Wrong Turn or Wolf Creek this ain't it. Definitely not a serious film.

But.....even if you enjoy horror movies with a twist I found it lacking. The reveal near the end wasn't worth the 45 + minutes of "huh whats going on?"

It was very funny. I found myself cracking up quite a few times. The jump factor is also good along with some creative CG. All and all the movie is just OK entertainment. Reviewers who call it groundbreaking must be teenagers who really haven't been around the block with Hitchcock and Corman.

It does however remind a lot of a film I watched awhile back and really enjoyed which was called Waxwork. A fun campy horror movie not to be taken seriously and no CG. Check it out if you liked Cabin in the Woods.

title: I'm Buying Whedon's Wild Theory
review:
"A Cabin in the Woods" had received so much critical praise as an excellent horror film, so this horror movie fan could not resist a bait like that. I did not read anything about the plot nor have I seen the trailer before going into the theater this morning. What can I say, this must be one of the most convoluted horror stories ever put in screen!

It starts with a couple of old guys in an unspecified company talking about their mundane lives. Then, the focus cuts to some college kids who were about to go on a road trip. It is only later when you see the connection between these two disparate sets of characters. We would then see a situation seen in countless horror flicks where the characters are trapped in a lonely cabin in the God-forsaken woods where they are killed off one by one by zombie rednecks. But is that all there really is to it?

The five college kids are stereotypical of what we see in practically every horror movie we had ever seen before: the whore, the athlete, the scholar, the fool and the virgin. Cliché you say, but this literally multi-layered script by wunderkind writer Josh Whedon (who just gave us the masterpiece called "The Avengers") would actually attempt to explain why these five characters should be present in all horror movies all over the world. I know that sentence probably made no sense, but that is the main premise of this over-reaching screenplay. You would never imagine what the bigger story would be, and who actually gets to deliver the explanatory lines towards the end.

Acting is not a focus here, and it may actually be intentionally bad as a send-up to most horror flicks. Chris Hemsworth does not really act or look like Thor here, and could actually be played by any jock actor and would not make a difference. The computer-generated effects were excellent especially in the grand mayhem scenes where practically all the horror creatures of movie lore make a gory appearance. This ambitious conceit would be the main bone of contention of those who like and dislike this complicated film: do you buy Whedon's wild theory or not? I certainly liked it and I'm buying it.

title: Subverting clichés for something original and fun
review:
Behind this cliché title and cliché premise hides something quite different and original. I repeat what everyone else has been writing about it, the less you know about, the better. I'll just expand a little on what made this so good in my own opinion. The main characters were not selfish jerks, they were actually likable, and you'll even root for some of them. Even though they fit in the standard horror character stereotypes, initially they were not and basically how they "turned" into those stereotypes was cleverly explained. The all-around good acting: serious but not too serious, light but not parodic, certainly helped matters and kept the movie tone just right. Cabin in the Woods didn't take its viewers for imbeciles: it was smart, had a few humdinger plot twists and once again played with those famous horror clichés subverting them in the process. This movie actually explained most of them, but I can't tell you how.

The directing was professional and easy to follow, even spectacular sometimes. There was a reveal about 3/4 of the way through(involving cubes), that had been hinted at previously that made this film mind-blowingly cool and paved the way for a seriously action-packed and unpredictable last act, something I've never seen in any horror movie and I've seen a lot. Horror fans will in fact probably enjoy it more because they'll get most of the references. Josh Whedon fans (Buffy, Angel, Dollhouse), will get a blast of seeing a few old familiar acting faces. It doesn't mean that non-horror aficionados won't enjoy it, too, because the Cabin is quite unconventional and it's not too gory compared to many other genre entries. To be fair, I found the movie way more entertaining than scary, probably because I'm too desensitized to the horrific aspects by now. I thought the jump scares and surprises were effectively done, although it's not a particularly atmospheric film. Weirdly, I think that Cabin in the Woods will become a genre-defining film.
