With many critics stating that this is not a true slasher-film, and that this film is ridiculously overdone, I am here to state that regardless of the fact that the film may be overdone, it is just as true and genuine of a slasher film as any classic, such as Scream or A Nightmare on Elm Street, The Cabin in the Woods has just modernized the slasher genre in order to appeal the typical twenty first century audiences.

title: This film is a must see. A good film to show new to horror movie watchers!
review: This movie puts an interesting twist to the horror/slasher film genre. The acting (Hemsworth, Polk, Mikalski and others) was by far some of the best in modern horror films. Not that this movie required amazing acting, it required realistic acting which was portrayed very well. What sets this movie apart is its lurid monsters and death scenes. While being "scary" it was not to gruesome, which allows a wide variety of audiences that I think would enjoy this film. Cabin In The Woods has two running stories in one film (which is something I have not seen before in horror films). While we see the typical teenager mini-vacation and drugs and alcohol, the audience views an almost "behind the scenes" version of what seems to be an institution trying to kill them. As the kids fight for their survival, and underlying message of world destruction comes to surface. All of this is brilliance in its authenticity of writing and directing by Goddard. I strongly recommend movie to all people young and old who are looking for a chilling, intriguing movie. I always judge my views on films by if they were memorable or not, and this film (especially the last scene) was very memorable. In a life or death situation how far would you go to save yourself and the world?

title: Insane, just insane.
review: I'm not sure where to begin with The Cabin in the Woods without giving too much away. This will be brief and probably not very helpful, but this films needs to be seen with as little known about it as possible. Five friends go on vacation to a... yes you named it... cabin in the woods. They're overseen by two office workers, Richard Jenkins and Bradley Whitford, from an underground-lab. What beholds the holiday- goers? Words cannot describe. Drew Goddard pumps out cliché after cliché, only to slap us in the face with outrageousness. This is unique, gory and funny, thanks to Joss Whedon's writing skills. Watch this, but be warned, you will never be prepared.

title: An inventive, tongue-in-cheek horror comedy with both scares and laughs to fuel the party
review:
With Hollywood running progressively low on fresh ideas for the horror genre, Drew Goddard and writer Joss Whedon become heroes of reinventing the horror genre in ways many fans may not expect. This teen- oriented slasher flick is by no means a newborn concept, but it offers a surprisingly sensational idea that scores the solid achievement of evenly balancing laughs with over-the-top scares and gore, while poking fun at typical horror movie stereotypes. The result is a slick comedy/horror hybrid that sustains with an execution that is undoubtedly silly, but not meant to be taken seriously, at least when it comes to spewing dark morbid humor at every turn. This horror- comedy follows five college friends head out to spend a nice weekend at the lake, while staying at a lone cabin deep in the woods. These college friends include muscle-head jock Kurt (played by Chris Hemsworth), his sexy girlfriend Jules (played by Anna Hutchinson), average, smart guy Holden (played by Jesse Williams), clean cut Dana (played by Kristen Connonlly),and an absent-minded stoner Marty (played by Fran Kranz). What starts out as a fun night of drinking and truth-or-dare quickly turns into a nightmare when a horde of zombie killers come out of nowhere and begin attacking. Now why does this happen exactly? Well, the hideous creatures are summoned and controlled by no one other than a group of technicians of a secret underground facility, where the teenagers are unknowingly being watched from hidden security cameras inside the cabin. So the teenagers must escape and survive against the chaotic, gore-filled monster onslaught.

This is not your average, everyday horror film that some come to expect. Drew Goddard and Joss Whedon take the horror-genre and slaps it with a nice tongue-in-cheek approach that may feel reminiscent to Sam Raimi's 'Evil Dead' franchise. Mixing Truman Show-like elements with the monster invasion concept, this film sets it focus on a group of college-aged party animals who must survive against a monstrous rampage conducted unlike no way ever before. That is where the diabolical-minded scientists based in a secret laboratory come in. Using their cutthroat (and unrealistic) computer programming skills, this team of technicians become to villainous hand behind pitting the lead characters in a battle against an enormous variety of monstrous figures. With evil little creatures ranging from flying pteradactyls, to Gremlin-like little monsters, to killer unicorns, to plain zombie-like minions, the plot escalates into a bombastic, monster onslaught, eliciting just enough laughs, scares, and gallons of blood and gore to entertain audiences on both sides of the comedy/horror spectrum. These sequences are profoundly scary, but spare just enough elbow room from a few good laughs. In the process, the film takes fairly swell advantage of its silliness. If there is ever a point where the film's silliness slides past the line of necessary, it would most certainly be the ending which ends the film in a rather overblown fashion, even for the already goofy premise. Nonetheless, there is also an appealing cast to be offered in the bunch. Chris Hemsworth, Kristen Connolly, and Jesse Williams provide slices of charisma, while Fran Kranz becomes a source of gut-busting humor with his goofiness inherited by his pot-smoking behavior. Then there is Anna Hutchinson who operates as a little more than a surplus of titillation and eye-candy in two scenes during the second half, for better or worse.

The Cabin in The Woods is an inventive, tongue-in-cheek comedy/horror entry with an appealing blend of over-the-top horror and comedic spirit. It is an entertaining ride for both comedy and horror fans, or perhaps anyone who can buy into the absurd premise. The film is not by no means meant to engage viewers at an intellect level. If you are not pursuing something particularly intelligent, then you have come to the right place.

title: Blood and Lore: Cabin is a Revisionist Take on Scary Films
review:
In the 1985 film "Fright Night", Roddy MacDowall's hammy veteran of vampire films makes a self-aware observation that informs the proceedings of 2011's "Cabin in the Woods": "Nobody wants to see vampire killers... or vampires (anymore)... Apparently all they want to see are demented madmen running around in ski-masks, hacking up young virgins." If someone unexposed to horror films from the past 35 years or so were to watch a marathon of several of these films back to back--and let's say none of them were sequels--how many would it take before he or she began to predict what's going to happen next? For an American film audience that has by now endured the irony-heavy Scream franchise and the gloomily anti-ironic spate of "torture porn" from directors like Eli Roth and others, can there truly be any genuine shocks in horror anymore? "Cabin in the Woods" film attempts to answer that question with a wink and a nod.

"Cabin" features five college-aged protagonists, each fitting a certain stock cliché to be found in assorted horror films. There's the jock and de facto leader (Chris Hemsworth), the dumb blonde (Anna Hutchison), the nerd (Jesse Williams, who also serves as his group's token minority), the druggie (Fran Kranz) and the nice girl (Kristin Connolly). The slight twist is, not all of the characters inhabit these roles from the get-go, but are manipulated into them.

A creepy gas station attendant (is there any other kind in these films?) gives an oblique warning--to the students and the audience--as the quintet heads up to the titular cabin for a weekend of unsupervised fun. Before the film is over, threads from Deliverance, Friday the 13th, Ju-On/The Grudge and more are touched on in various depths. The Saw films, which are already on their seventh (or is that VIIth) installment, are also clipped for some thematic DNA.

The film was co-written by Joss Whedon ("Marvel's The Avengers") and directed by Drew Goddard--the latter of whom wrote and directed several episodes of Whedon's "Buffy" and "Angel" TV series as well as the conspiracy-heavy TV drama Lost. Both collaborators bring a satirical sensibility to this horror entry. Cabin reveals its core conceit in its opening scenes (though less-knowing viewers may be hard-pressed to connect the dots early on), and so perhaps the film has less bite (pun intended) than it would have were it to wait until later. Still, the twists, when they happen, are more intriguing than draining, especially by the climax, which manages to be nihilistic and liberating at the same time.

Cabin functions as a witty indictment and an apology of sorts for the clichés of contemporary horror cinema and the slasher subgenre in particular. Depending on how cynical the viewer is, the only way to really ruin this experience would be to have a sequel.

title: Amazingly astounding and funny
review:
The premise is very familiar, 5 college friends go into a cabin deep inside the woods for a fun weekend and hell ensues, in this occasion hell REALLY ensues.

Writers Joss Whedon (The Avengers) and Drew Goddard (Netflix's Daredevil) are giving us a completely different take on the genre that I personally didn't see coming. Of course the young people are attacked, dismembered, killed in all cruel ways imaginable but behind it all there is a higher purpose for their death (I am not joking).

It is a nice mixture of horror and a lot of comedy, something Whedon and Goddard are used to since their work on the popular Cult TV Show Buffy the Vampire Slayer.

I respect the filmmakers for using such a fresh approach to all of this and the result is one of the best movies of the genre I have ever seen.

It might not be scary, it might be campy... but it is so much fun.

title: A benchmark in modern horror...
review:
This film had been recommended to me countless times but I forgot all about it, so you can imagine the sweet surprise I got when I found it for sale on Amazon. Joss has created another favorite of mine, if not the favorite, this film offers countless different monsters including zombies, werewolves, cenobites, witches, ghosts and much more. I admire the clever mix of countless horror genres as well as other horror films. The practical and CGI effects are incredible giving us great monsters and awesome gore. The only reason I will give it 9 out of ten is because the twist was ruined for me by social media.

Over all a great movie and a great watch for horror fans.

I recommend you watch this film.

title: Go in with zero expectations, and have a good time
review:
Okay, so there's a lot of controversy amongst the watchers of this film, half saying it's a cinematic masterpiece and the other half saying it's dreadful. I know mine is just another opinion, but hear me out.

This film is garbage. It's complete Hollywood-Indie trash, with Whedon practically acting like a three year old who had way too much money left over after the first Avengers film and just went "aaaaaaah fudge it" and made one of the most overdone messes of a film I've seen in years. And I ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT.

It. Is. Garbage. It take satire to a whole new level, actually managing to miss it completely in parts. It's loud and crowded and overacted and underdeveloped, and it comes out as this dirty little diamond amongst a genre that really does take itself way too seriously most of the time.

The concept is excellent, with the scientist/occultist crew literally so overdone i nearly cried with laughter every time they spoke, and the menagerie of monsters an absolute delight in their selection (the mermaid, I will never recover).

Yes, it's not brilliantly acted- thats the bloody point! This whole movie is meant to be a laugh (and if you didn't laugh at Hemsworth's character's abrupt departure from the film you have poor taste because that was comedy gold), and even the monster bloodbath in the final quarter is crafted specifically for humour.

There are a few scares, particularly towards the start, but as the movie goes on the warped humour of it all takes the foreground, and I honestly found the lack of bothers this film gave a very refreshing thing to watch.

So basically, if you are out there looking for a super well crafted and suspenseful horror film, this isn't the go to for you. But, if you want a movie that is nothing like you've seen before (and you'll probably be glad about that) with just enough scare to feed your masochistic tendencies, and a very typical Whedon flare, look no further.

This movie made me want to hit my head against a wall until I passed out, only so I could regain consciousness and probably watch it again. Give it a go with an open mind and you may just be surprised.

title: Perfection!
review:
I read somewhere that this movie had been referred to as being a love letter to horror movie fans everywhere and I figured it had to be hyperbole. I have never been happier to be proved wrong.

I won't spoil the movie for those who haven't seen it, and describing anything about the plot would almost assuredly do so, but it was amazing.

I recommend that anyone who enjoys horror of any kind, but especially the more cerebral variety, should get one hell of a kick out of this one. There was an almost perfect mixture of horror and self-referential humor.

title: Lovecraftian Horror
review: Yes, this film is a spoof of slasher/teen/cabin films. It makes no apologies for that. However, if you've ever bothered to familiarize yourself with H.P., you are truly no horror fan. Yes, it makes fun of the typical Jason/Michael/Hills Have Eyes genre. But it is rather original in that it delves into a totally different scheme. It is camera en camera as well as a dark humor style I absolutely found intriguing. It brings us to a level of laughing at teen horror film styles, then interjects something far more adult in nature.It actually made people resume their interest in Lovecraft. You who thought this film sucked, was actually one of the best on IMDb.

title: More of a true horror movie than most reviews let on.
review:
I was hoping for a horror-comedy along the lines of "Shawn of the Dead", but instead this movie is much closer to a straight up horror movie, albeit with a clever plot and some comedic elements and witty bits.

I don't care that much for horror movies, although I am up on what goes on in the genre, so I think I got all of the jokes and references in this one. It's meta and satire in the same way as the "Scream" franchise, but I feel it was much harsher in terms of horror effects and plot.

If you are into horror movies, I'm guessing that you're going to love this film, but it's just not my thing. I am still rating it highly, because I have to grant that it was very well done and an unexpected twist on conventional horror movies, and I can't quite say I regret watching it.

title: The Cabin in the Woods (8/10)
review: Cabin in the Woods takes your typical campy horror plot, a bunch of kids, on a weekend getaway, to a remote cabin and flips everything you know about that, upside down. Joss Whedon and Drew Goodard wrote an incredibly creative horror script, well not according to Peter Gallagher, but in terms of the onslaught of prequels, sequels, and remakes, it does. The cast for this movie was near perfect. Richard Jenkins's and Bradley Whitford's characters were hilarious, yet ruthless. The five youthful campers are headlined by Kristen Connolly and Chris Hemsworth, a couple big catches, since some might consider these risky roles. Once the movie's plot turns away from its "Evil Dead" type feel, into its whacky rabbit hole, the movie starts to get extremely interesting. Horror generalizations, elements, monsters, one liner's and themes are poured into this zany film. Is Cabin in the Woods ridiculous, yes, is it absurd and deranged, yes. Is it also a fun thrilling ride completely original to anything recently, most definitely! There are a few questionable eye rolling moments but overall it's a great watch, perhaps one of the top films of the twenty-tens decade.

title: no grades .
review: i originally gave it a 6 , but after getting the subconscious message , i gave it an 8 . first of all , i don't know if a rating system can be adjusted to fit the subconscious measures . so lets go deeper . i originally saw this film , as a funny horror film , a nice one for our times that are filled with garbage . at a second view (or maybe was a third ) i saw that this film is dedicated to human civilization , and technical evolution that made unworthy people making decisions for the worthy ones . in both sides , are people from our times . the young ones that are having fun , and the older ones or the ones in the system , that try to manipulate the unfit , to fed the human centipede of hierarchy that is represented with monsters that try to terrify the masses over the passed times .

title: Unsettling Fantastic Piece of Work
review: The Cabin in the Woods was a really different kind of horror movie. Instead of using the basic pop-out scares and unsettling character traits, this movie has combined the use of a cursed object that teenagers merely find in the basement of a cabin in the woods. From the start of the movie to the end, I was excited and prepared to have my mind blown and my body thrown out of my seat as I'd experience this new kind of horror movie genre. The Cabin in the Woods was a completely new vision of the kind of horror that I love to be apart of. This movie contained the essence of a laboratory underground run by a secret organization who sells the picture of different haunts throughout the world. The movie was more seen as an experiment (literally) where different monsters locked in boxes underground get summoned by different artifacts that any stranger could find in their home or school. These monsters were designed to kill the people who summoned them so the cooperate office underground running the show, could have higher ratings. The movie was more than unsettling, it was a complete turn from a regular everyday scary movie that you would see with your friends. To me, it is defined as the start of a new legacy of scary movies since 2012.

title: Quite Good
review:
I love horror movies, but this is not a horror movie for me. More of a sci-fi or even mystery or something. What I wanna say is that I was not scared at all! But I did enjoy most of the film.

What I did not like was the end with all those monsters... They kinda looked fairytale to me - though not all of them!

I really liked the idea of the film, especially reality show thing. And I must say that at first, or better say first few minutes I was puzzled whether I was really starting to watch the beginning of the film or it was something else totally random!

All in all, quite good. Not scary but not boring either. It does grab your attention, so from me - 8 !

title: Weaker than it should be but still solid enough
review:
Heading out to a cabin in the woods, a group of friends finds that their actions have stirred a dark, evil presence nearby and must try to fight for their lives only to learn of a far greater threat within.

This was quite a fun and enjoyable entry that has a lot of really fun things about it. One of the better elements to this one is the fact that there's just enough comedy here to play this off as a parody yet still be taken completely seriously. Because this one is so heavily built around clichés and utilizes them to their fullest extent here really drives this one not only by partaking in the clichés but then offering a rather unique take on that need for the clichéd nature of these prototypical stories. This in turn drives up the rather ingenious storyline here where it builds on these types and then sets them into action against numerous enemies as this one kicks in with some rather dark and chilling takes on the prototypical killer-in-the-woods types. Not only is this section of the film pretty dark, creepy and packed with plenty of chilling encounters but it also runs through some rather ingenious moments to keep this one going along quite nicely throughout as there's enough action and gore here to really satisfy here. Unfortunately, what doesn't work here is everything after that point which is the last half-hour of the film as this delves into an over-developed and needless exploration of what's going on that's not in the slightest bit clever, original or worthwhile. Trying to hide behind tons of gory bloodshed doesn't help disguise the fruitless endeavor this tries to undertake all in the name of trying to be original or clever and never is all that enjoyable for it. This isn't enough to really knock this down, but it's enough to lower this slightly.

Rated R: Extreme Graphic Violence, Extreme Graphic Language, Nudity and continuous drug use.

title: A Hilarious Send-Up and Fitting Tribute to the Horror Genre
review:
I don't know what I was expecting, but Cabin in the woods wasn't it. It was a hundred times more awesome. It starts just like any other horror movie. No, make that every other horror movie. Five teens, including a jock, a slut, a stoner, a nerd, and a shy pretty girl head for a weekend of partying at a remote cabin none of them has ever been to before. And it's not long before they realize that something is very, very wrong, and that there's no way out and no-one to save them.

So yeah, it sounds like another clichéd horror clone, except that it's not. Because Joss Whedon doesn't do hackneyed formula movies. That's why from the very beginning, Cabin in the Woods jams in every horror cliché in existence, dials them up to eleven, slathers on the comic relief, and turns the whole thing on its head. And the result is oddball, over the top, blood soaked, side splitting, and made of pure win.

Cabin follows a fairly standard three part arc, which is just about the only standard thing about it. In the first act the setting is established, the characters do all the stupid things people in a horror movie should never do, and not so subtle hints of what's to come are dropped. In act two, evil is awakened and teenagers begin dying in grisly fashion, at a rate that makes you wonder if the movie will reach the one hour mark. And then the third act takes everything in a direction that only Whedon could have come up with.

Without giving anything away, the important thing to understand is that there are bigger things at work than a few teens and zombies. There are powerful players with global reach watching their every move and manipulating every event, but they're actually not that bad once you get to know them. And that's part of the brilliance of Cabin in the Woods, the combination of seemingly mismatched elements that work together to create outrageousness and hilarity; graphic violence and stoner wisdom, evil conspiracies and office parties, zombies and werewolves plus unicorns and the sugar plum fairy.

The other thing that makes Cabin brilliant is that it's the antithesis of Scary Movie. It's a smart satire that actually skewers the common elements of American (and occasionally Japanese) horror movies instead of just making references and fart jokes. It takes all the old clichés, deconstructs them, and has a lot of fun doing it. When it does make references, they're clever and often subtle. And it has a plot that matters and makes sense. Plus it's not just a great comedy; it's a competent horror film with sudden shocks, gruesome deaths, and moments of real terror.

This was one of the most original and entertaining movies I have seen in a very long time. As horror comedies go it may even be better than Zombieland or Shaun of the Dead, though I admit that's up for debate. All I know is that I could not stop laughing, and the ending had me holding my sides, then cheering, then doing an air guitar solo. (When you see it you'll understand why.) This movie is pure unadulterated awesomeness. If a friend asks if you want to watch Scary Movie or whatever exorcism movie is coming out this month, bring this one instead.

title: Innovative and entertaining
review:
I heard a lot about this movie before I decided to see it. Since I am not a horror fan, I wasn't crazy about seeing it, but the more I heard about the more I got intrigued. One day, I decided to rent it and just see it. The result was an interesting and entertaining ride with unexpected results.

1) The acting. Since the movie is not (primarily) focused on the teens I found that the two pillars of the movie are Jenkins and Whitford. The positive energy these two emit from the screen is contagious. It is obvious that they had so much fun acting that it is just a pleasure to watch them. But, the problem is, they were having such a good time acting two demonic and evil characters. The job that they do is disturbing beyond sanity, but their energy and fun made me root for them instead for the teens. And that is what disturbed me the most. This is one of the most interesting elements of the movie, the ones you are supposed to root for you want dead, and the bad guys are the ones who you are rooting for. The teens are so generic that there is almost nothing I can say about them. But, the point of the movie is to make them (too) generic, in fact one of the plot points is based on that. But, Kranz did a really good job. He was entertaining even more that it was intended, and he raised his character a little out of the boundaries, which was more than entertaining and fun to watch.

2) The story. The thing one must understand is that this movie mocks all other teen-horror/slasher horror ever made. Elements of every cult horror can be found in this movie: Evil dead, Friday the 13th, almost every zombie movie ever made etc. Now, some would say that the movie is a copycat of all those movies, but the plot line is so ingenious that all those elements actually make sense and do not feel copied, but as well placed puzzle pieces. In all my years of watching movies I have never seen a movie that plays with horror elements so well. The climax is almost completely unexpected and innovative that one just can't believe it ended the way it did. Still, about two thirds into the movie the paste and story changes so abruptly that it leaves you stunned. The problem with it is that the change is explained too fast and too simple. The way the movie develops afterward is a bit rushed and the focus gets a bit lost. Still, the finale is exceptional and quite fitting for this movie. If the third part of the movie was a bit longer and more focused the final product would have been even more fun and interesting that it actually is.

Every other aspect of the movie is not worth mentioning. It would be quite strange that a 95 min mystery-horror-comedy had more to offer than good acting and a great story with a couple of jump scares and quite a bit of gore. It is important to remember that everything you see has a reason, and if something feels familiar, that feeling is also there for a reason. An open mind and a box of popcorn with this movie guaranties a great evening.

title: I get it...
review:
With this movie, people either really loved it or really hated it and I get both. Lets face it, most horror movies start out with a group of young people who usually end up getting picked off one by one- sometimes 2 at a time. Maybe there are 5 of them- maybe 2. For the most part, even Saw had younger people- even though they were killed in different ways. But there aren't many horror movies where the stars are middle aged people. Also- these young people are normally the athlete, the quiet one, the spacey one- usually on some kind of drugs, and a number of other clichés.

My point is that the beginning of this movie is like every other horror movie you've seen. Then it changes... If you like out of the box thinking- and Joss Whedon- you'll like this. I didn't like it right after I watched it- but then after I thought about it and realized just how clever it was- I liked it a lot.

title: The best horror flick since Scream
review:
Cabin in the woods is the best horror movie i have seen since Scream, it takes all the Horror genre's and plays them back not to type.

So the movie starts with a office or facility with normal office types engaging in normal general chit chat, which puts us the viewer at unease as we think hey this is a Horror movie whats going on here ?

So then we are introduced to a group of Standard Horror characters in your staple road trip to a Cabin in the woods. We have seen this before with the likes of Cabin Fever, The Evil Dead and your Friday the 13th films just to name a few.

The horror cliques are played to the max, the geek, the Virgin, the Jock, the easy girl. All enter the cabin and nothing much happens for a while till the observers (those in the office) open a hatch into the Cellar, surely a nod to the Evil Dead ?

Everyone knows "Don't go into the cellar", but of course they will and they do, and this is where the twist comes as unwittingly these teens choose their own demise with out realising it.

You see down in the cellar are some artifacts that when chosen of interacted with bring out a certain monster. To carry on and reveal what comes next will spoil a film you simply must see

title: Is it funny? Yes. Is it scary? No.
review:
The Cabin in the Woods is a horror comedy that takes a very strange concept and manages to make it work. Judging from the trailers, one can pick up the basic premise of the movie: Several young adults going to a Cabin in the Woods that is being run by a testing facility that will try to control their decisions to play out horror movie tropes.

The interesting thing about The Cabin in the Woods is that it is surprisingly predictable. You pretty much know what's going to happen next. You can tell that certain characters that are fleshed out are going to survive and that the simplistic and "boring" characters will die. However, I will say that it is still a very entertaining movie.

The nice thing about this movie is that its premise is very outlandish and part of its humor comes from irony and the very "business" like aspects of the film. The movie literally reuses classic horror movie tropes and explains that the reason those tropes exist is because it is all run by the same organization that tries to play out specific scenarios.

It is hard to review this movie without revealing too much. The Cabin in the Woods is definitely an entertaining movie for horror movie fans and it has some clever ideas. However, the movie isn't ingenious by any means. It is simply a fun movie.

title: Either you think its a 10 or 0
review:
Either you think its a 10 or 0 There are some here that just don't get a fun horror movie. They think its above them or they have no need to laugh at parodies.

Um you aren't clever for seeing common horror plot themes - as that was the point!! Its like being sarcastic, and someone pointing out its incorrect. NO DUH IDIOT - talk about being the smartest child in the room filled with down syndrome!

Those that rated it a 10, understand the jokes and the parodies. This is an awesome movie, fun at many turns, a few odd surprises that all leads up to a simple explosion of anything and everything you can think of at the end.

Those that don't get it, are simply idiots and more likely boring. You'd want to spend about 5 minutes with them and then leave their company in avoidance of wasting your life. They are the type that think the Rocky horror picture show is strange and silly, or think that Raising Arizona isn't funny. They simply don't get it - They never will.

This is a definitely a cult movie. People who don't like horror movies will even like this one, and may cringe a little, but then laugh when all hell breaks loose. Bring popcorn !

title: Lots of blood let in really cool ways.
review: Now this was a fun movie to watch and while away a rainy and windy Fall day. A+ See it. Horror at its best. Made me laugh with pleasure. Loved it. Zombies were beautiful, well, in there own way of course. The monsters were many and varied. The special effects were novel and masterful. Weird take on Big Brother, really weird. Sigourney Weaver -perfect for the role, especially know her movie history. Good call there. Who would dis this flick? Not your normal horror, cabin in the woods, lost teenagers, stab them and slab them movie. WOuld have liked to see this in a theater. A+, but I wrote that already. This is not Freddie Krueger or Jason or any of those. It is not Hellboy. This movie stands on its own. A bit of a disjointed review I know, but I am feeling a bit giddy with pleasure right now. Usually I avoid these "cabin" movies but I sure am glad I found this one.

title: The fantastic "The Cabin in the Woods" (2012) is a surprise-filled movie that is difficult to review without spoilers ...
review:
... so I can't say much about it. Suffice to say, I really, really liked it – I'd give it a 9 out of 10.

This is a smart, inventive film that is probably the most creative thing I've seen in a long time – it's safe to say that I've never seen anything like it. Do yourself a favor and avoid news articles or websites like IMDb.com – you'll enjoy this much more if you know little about it.

It actually takes a while to get going. I had a lukewarm response to this movie for maybe its entire first half. The end — which brings together a surprising number of story elements (I really can't say more) – really redeemed it. The buildup to that ending is a lot of things that have long been established as horror clichés. But that's intentional, as screenwriter Drew Goddard and producer Joss Whedon made it, I think, partly as a parody and partly as an homage to the genre.

A few caveats  if you've been looking forward to this movie for a while, as I have, you're aware that it was very well reviewed. But I'm pretty sure it got so much praise because it was creative and original – not because it was the best HORROR movie ever made. The central plot device is too contrived and fantastic to be really frightening, and the movie is too self-aware to allow us to forget it's just a movie. Parts of it were disturbing, but there's just too much humor to make this a truly scary movie. You're not sitting down to "The Exorcist" or "The Shining."

Also, various reviews seem to indicate a twist that is impossible to guess. This isn't true. Horror fans – especially fans of a certain subgenre – will know the big reveal before the halfway mark, especially if they listen to the dialogue of the story's antagonists. Hell, I was just talking about it with another aspiring horror writer just the other day. Don't expect a surprise on the level of "The Sixth Sense" or "Unbreakable."

Still, this was a hell of a lot of fun. And what a GREAT Halloween movie it would make!! It would also be fun to watch back-to-back with "Cabin Fever" or one of the "Evil Dead" movies, given their similar settings.

http://ericrobertnolan.wordpress.com/

title: I loved it but it's so weird 0_o
review:
I really enjoyed watching this movie but it is truly the weirdest movie I've ever watched. There is something new every second and you wouldn't get bored at all. They can make many sequels of it and in each one there will be a new twist.

The movie begins like all road trip horror movies in an RV driving in an unknown road to find themselves at an abandoned gas station with a creepy owner but no, as they continue driving and enter the tunnel, you will for sure know that this movie has a very different and twisted plot than the stereotyped road trip movies. " Won't say anything more, watch it for yourself " :P

The movie has many weird and unexplained scenes but this what makes it thrilling, but it's not really scary and there are no horrifying scenes at all, they might be shocking but not scary " for me at least".

I really hoped that at the end that all of this was kinda a virtual video game or something and and when it's over, everything will go back the same but unfortunately it wasn't.

So, great movie, well executed but I wished that the end was different as it is a bit selfish.

title: Perfectly judged
review:
This is a funny, gory, beautifully structured movie. There are some genuinely scary moments, as well as a number of set pieces that are jaw-droppingly good. There is, I must admit, a gaping unlikelihood in an otherwise solidly-put-together story, but bigger, bloodier events prevent you from lingering over it.

Its running time has been perfectly judged. Having sat through 130 heavy-going minutes of DAWN OF THE PLANET OF THE APES a few nights before made me particularly grateful for the slim, trim pace of CABIN.

I was watching it for the third time. It's turning into one of my favourites.

title: Truly a masterpiece of the Horror Genre
review: I gave this film a full 10 stars as it is one of the few that I felt truly deserve such a rating. Far too often we see horror films, where at least one person lives and all is right with the world at the end. The Cabin In The Woods does not do this or at least that is what we are left to believe at the end. We do not know the true outcome, though we are left with an idea from which we draw our own conclusions. The ancient ones apparently rise, but at that point the credits roll. The addition of comedy to this film makes it that much more enjoyable as I found myself laughing at some of the dialogue. This is not because it was so stupid it was funny, but because it was genuinely written to be funny and succeeded at such. The cast performed beautifully and the movie is what I would call a must see. I've seen some negative reviews for this movie and I have to wonder what movie those individuals were watching. It obviously wasn't this one. The premise of the movie is one that I've not seen done in this manner previously or at least not with this level of success. All in all, this is a must see movie.

title: Modern smart allegorical and If you think you know this story, think again :)
review: I am so tired to watching typical Bhut (ghost) k shock! I was expecting for the best horror movie among 2/3 years and at last I choose this. It became one of my most favorite horror movies. What do I say? It's a dark satirical metaphorical comedy Horror ( that's what I think in my way!) By God it has a sex appeal. You have to find it yourself. As usual in the 1st half the story goes typical like -- Five friends go for a break at a remote cabin in the woods, where they get more than they bargained for. Together, they must discover the truth behind the cabin in the woods. If you think you know this story, think again. This time you are wrong Awarded By so many prizes, rated 7.1 / 73%, according to IMDb and Rotten Tomatoes, written by Goddard and Whedon (Buffy the Vampire Slayer and Angel)! Find out what society and media can do. It's nothing but a Bitchy bitch and you are also going to be killed... Soon

title: Great film, Entertaining on many different levels
review: This film totally took me by surprise. I expected a simple plot with lame scares scattered throughout, but this movie is far more complex than I thought it would be. The satirical humor of the desensitized human society in this time period is quite funny, and although it may be ridiculous at times, it accentuates the message being presented about human culture. The acting wasn't top notch, but the characters were developed well, and the action throughout the film was not only exhilarating and fun to watch, but also moved the character development along at a perfect pace. Overall, the film was put together outstandingly, and it was a pleasure to watch.

title: Oh my God! This is the worst film in the world history!!!
review:
This is really the worst film in the world history. There are hundreds or thousands of films that are worse than this, but this cost serious money to make and it makes me wonder: what where the producers thinking!?

The guy who's constantly stoned (Marty) is unbearable. It's ridiculous. I've been hanging out with people who where smoking marijuana all the time in my twenties and I've never met anybody who was talking like this guy.

The acting is high-school-student-taking-acting-lessons level. Really lame. I should have known. When you see a bunch of unknown beautiful actors, you can't expect anything better than this.

The film has no logic, creates NO ILLUSION AT ALL, and the only thing I can think of about people who rate it with 10, is that their IQ is much below average.

title: I think this movie was labelled wrong...but I still liked it.
review: I gave this movie a six because while it is very confusing, it is also entertaining. It is under the genres Horror, Mystery, and Thriller. If anything I would have labeled it under Comedy, Parody, and maybe tacked Mystery on at the end. This movie was kind of hilarious. Both me and the person I was watching it with laughed throughout the movie. We kept having to look back at what category it was under because we could not believe that it wasn't a comedy or parody. I don't understand why it is under the horror genre because though it has the classic elements of a scary movie, it is also seems to be making fun of that fact. And the things that would have made it only a scary movie (the parts with the cabin and zombies) were constantly interrupted with funny dialogue from the people watching them. Not that that is a bad thing! If those funny parts were taken out it would have just been another utterly forgettable B horror film. All around I think that this is a fun movie. It was not what we were expecting when we picked out a "scary" movie, but we enjoyed it nonetheless.

title: A satire about our dark ritual
review:
Most seem to peg "The Cabin in the Woods" as either a traditional horror film with a neat twist or a predictable horror film that becomes increasingly ridiculous. However, a literal viewing the story totally misses the point.

It's quite clear that this film is a satire, not so much a parody of the genre as a vehicle for the filmmakers to poke fun at you, the audience, "the Ancients," whose unquenchable thirst for blood must be appeased.

The NASA-like technical team that "produces" the "sacrifice"—with precision and professionalism, totally detached from any moral culpability, ensuring every single moment "sticks to the script"—these might just represent filmmakers, or more generally, the Hollywood system.

I think this is what makes this film quite ingenious. It's sort of like a mainstream version of Haneke's "Funny Games." The filmmaker is trying to jolt you out of your somnambulistic film-watching routine and make you think about what you're doing and perhaps ask yourself some interesting and uncomfortable questions.

Why do we watch these films? Are we as sick as the people manning the controls? Is this really entertainment? Why must a film always live within the boundaries of the formula? And if it break the rules, will it really be the "end of the world"?

title: Smart yet Dumb
review:
OK. Enough of the artsy, fartsy Euro-drama stuff. Time for some good old-fashioned genre cinema of the horror pastiche variety. Whilst this may be directed by Drew Goddard it has the grubby finger-prints of Joss Wheedon all over it. Drenched with more genre in-jokes, post-modern and post-Scream horror references than you could shake a severed hand at Cabin in the Woods plays it's cards close to it's chest but it's love of genre proudly on it's sleeve.

So where do we begin without being suitably spoilerific. The setup is 5 young, dumb and of varying degrees of beautiful college types head off to the eponymous cabin in search of a weekend of fun in the flora and fauna (No, I don't see the attraction either). However, they're being watched before they even get there. There that's all I can say without giving anything away.

So what do we have here? Essentially, this is a live-action feature length episode of Scooby-doo for grown-ups (except without the talking dog. And that's the rub. Everything here is knowingly pastiche and stereotypical. The cast all fulfill fixed roles: the hunky-jock, the babe, the last-girl nerd, the stoner and the geek. The twists are twisty. The jokes are funny. The knowingness is er... knowingy. The scares unfortunately aren't really scary but I'm not sure they're supposed to be.

You see this homage/ pastiche/ parody/ whatever sticks so closely to conventions that it's hard to react to a scare you've seen done a thousand times before. But... and it's a big one... was it entertaining? Yes, big smartly dumb fun which is not a bad return for minimal brain investment.

title: Good watch, with friends for a movie night/drinks etc
review:
This movie was pretty funny and it was quite original as well. I do think they could have done a little bit better though. it wasn't too spoofy, it was definitely a good mix between horror and comedy. The ones that are so comical that it takes away from the fact its a horror get boring after a while it definitely isn't like the title suggests "the cabin in the woods". for me that title makes me think its going to be your typical slasher or ghost film, so this one was a nice surprise.

it was a mix between horror with the blood, guts and zombies,and syfy with the entire thing being an experiment and they cant get out.

I love the guys who are watching over the experiment, they are super funny.

one thing I only picked up on when the stoner mentioned it, because they didn't really emphasize, was that the game was changing their personalities. they could have done a bit better on that.

also nicely surprised when it didn't end where I thought it would.

its pretty cool how its all like elevators like the movie "cube", there were actually a few references to other movies in this I noticed.

I love when the elevators all open up and all the monsters come out, that was funny and its awesome how many different creatures and things were in the cube elevators, that was pretty inventive there.

the one thing I didn't really like was the "ritual" thing, I thought it would have been better to go along the lines of an experimental thing.

but without thinking too much into it, it was a good comedy horror, one to sit back with your mates, have a few drinks and have a good laugh while at the same time getting a bit squeamish or shocked!

title: Original
review:
After not watching a horror film in over 10 years I decided I would start with this one. It didn't sound too terrifying. I wasn't expecting much but I have to admit the originality of the film did capture me. I was disappointed with the ending and unfortunately it took me a while to understand what was going on for the first hour.

For the originality of the film, I gave it a 6. I also have to give credit to the fact it didn't end with the usual happy ending horror films have become accustomed to.

It did make me jump (once) at the opening credits, when my kitchen door mysteriously closed on its own (just what I needed!) There were a few parts that made me laugh too. However the blonde character was a rather poor actress. I am glad I watched it, but I wouldn't watch it again.

title: An innovative horror movie
review:
I thought Cabin in the Woods was an enjoyable movie with some creative twists on horror movie clichés wrapped around a decent horror movie.

First, the movie doesn't just deviate from the clichés but actively mocks them, and this is what really differentiates Cabin in the Woods from its peers. Unfortunately, this is also a weak point in the film because it's hard to play so directly with the clichés without coming off as campy. This leads to some of the most creative parts of the movie coming off as comedic and taking you out of the suspense and horror of the moment.

Outside of the twists, Cabin in the Woods is a decent horror movie. It doesn't rely excessively on gore and provides a mix of suspenseful and shock moment that keep you interested. However, there's nothing that really differentiates it from any other movie, and so anyone looking for a pure horror movie would be better off picking another film.

title: Don't watch the trailer!
review:
I saw the movie tonight and I was very surprised to see how good this movie is. I wanted to watch a horror movie, but the beginning of the film was strange and I thought about seeing another movie.

Im glad that I didn't stop. It's awesome! The story is really cool, I loved the way they made the supernatural and old with the technological and future.

The explanation of the story is very good, and the final scenes of the movie are awesome. I was watching with a friend and I keep pausing the movie to see everything that was happening.

If you really love horror movies you should watch this movie, there a lot of tributes to other horror films.
